conclusion: Understanding the problem of spring elongation with current through a metal rod.
Metal rod labeled ab suspended horizontally by two springs with length L, uniform density and thickness.
Springs have a spring constant k and are identical.
Rod is in a uniform magnetic field perpendicular to the paper and pointing into it.
Current I1 causes no stretch in springs, indicating equilibrium.
Need to find elongation when current direction is from b to a with magnitude I2.
In first scenario with current I1, springs do not stretch, indicating equilibrium with other forces.
Rod has weight mg acting downward.
Magnetic force on current-carrying wire is F = ILB.
Using right-hand rule, current from a to b and magnetic field into paper results in upward force.
Magnetic force upward balances weight downward: mg = I1LB.
In second scenario, current from b to a reverses magnetic force direction to downward.
Downward forces are mg and I2LB; springs provide upward force.
